comment_text.dn31:1.3: Sigālaka only appears in this sutta. His name means “little jackal”.
comment_text.dn31:1.4: Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.5.1 recommends offerings to Agni in the east, Indra or Soma in the south, the All-gods in the west, Mitra and Varuṇa in the north, and Bṛhaspati in the middle. The quarters themselves are divine, since one can travel them and never reach the end (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.1.5). Atharva Veda 12.3.7–10 gives a domestic prayer for the quarters; here Yama dwells in the south with the Fathers, while Soma is in the west, and the other directions are not associated with specific deities. Vājasaneyi Saṁhitā 22.24a worships the six directions. Maitrī Upaniṣad 7.1–6 details the spiritual meanings of the six quarters. In Buddhism, the quarters are said to be inhabited by the respective Four Great Kings as per DN 32.
comment_text.dn31:2.8: Sigālaka followed blindly without considering the meaning as urged by Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.3.11.
comment_text.dn31:2.12: It is unusual to find “six” directions. Normally it is four, then eight (with intermediate directions), then ten (above and below). Praśna Upaniṣad 1.6 lists the six, then the intermediates.
comment_text.dn31:3.1: The Buddha outlines the contents of the discourse to follow.
comment_text.dn31:3.5: The teaching is structured to reinforce memorization. Give the number of items (twice), so you will notice if any are missing; list the items; recapitulate the numbers; then recapitulate the items once more in verse.
comment_text.dn31:5.1: First we learned what the bad deeds were, now we learn why people do them.
comment_text.dn31:7.1: “Drains on wealth” is apāyamukha, literally “openings for departure”. This is emphasized here since Sigālaka wants to be a good son and not squander the family fortune.
comment_text.dn31:7.2: The most common phrase in Pali for alcoholic beverages lists three items. Surā is brewed from grains with yeast (Bu Pc 51:2.1.2) Meraya is made from flowers, fruits, or sugars (Bu Pc 51:2.1.4). Madya is apparently a catchall. Together they correspond fairly well with the modern classification of alcoholic drinks as “beer, wine, and liquor”. See also Manu 11.94, Arthaśāstra 2.25, Suśrutasaṁhitā 1.45, Amarakośodghāṭana 3.6.
comment_text.dn31:8.1: Now each of the six drains on wealth are expanded and explained.
comment_text.dn31:14.13: Vārunī is said to have been distilled from hogweed with palm sap, “toddy”.
comment_text.dn31:14.21: Assume vāruṇī is a truncated instrumental.
comment_text.dn31:14.24: Kāhiti is third person singular future of karoti.
comment_text.dn31:14.32: The subcommentary explains atthā as dhanā (“riches”).
comment_text.dn31:27.1: Having explained the six drains on wealth, the Buddha moves on to the next item in the table of contents.
comment_text.dn31:27.3: Parents are in the east because that is where the sun is born. Tutors are to the south (dakkhiṇā) as they are owed an offering (dakkhiṇā). Family is one’s legacy, so they lie with the setting sun in the west. Good friends keep you on the upright way to the north. Servants support you and make your life possible, like the earth below. And spiritual teachers lead you to heaven or transcendence above.
comment_text.dn31:29.4: “Protection in every region” (disāsu parittāṇaṁ) refers to when the student has completed their studies and goes off to travel, the teacher does what they can to ensure their safety in other regions.
comment_text.dn31:30.2: Marriage is based on mutual care and respect, not on dominance and obedience.

root_text.dn31:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
root_text.dn31:1.3: Tena kho pana samayena siṅgālako gahapatiputto kālasseva uṭṭhāya rājagahā nikkhamitvā allavattho allakeso pañjaliko puthudisā namassati—

root_text.dn31:2.1: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.dn31:2.2: Addasā kho bhagavā siṅgālakaṁ gahapatiputtaṁ kālasseva vuṭṭhāya rājagahā nikkhamitvā allavatthaṁ allakesaṁ pañjalikaṁ puthudisā namassantaṁ—
root_text.dn31:2.3: puratthimaṁ disaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ disaṁ pacchimaṁ disaṁ uttaraṁ disaṁ heṭṭhimaṁ disaṁ uparimaṁ disaṁ.
root_text.dn31:2.5: “kiṁ nu kho tvaṁ, gahapatiputta, kālasseva vuṭṭhāya rājagahā nikkhamitvā allavattho allakeso pañjaliko puthudisā namassasi—
root_text.dn31:2.6: puratthimaṁ disaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ disaṁ pacchimaṁ disaṁ uttaraṁ disaṁ heṭṭhimaṁ disaṁ uparimaṁ disan”ti?
root_text.dn31:2.7: “Pitā maṁ, bhante, kālaṁ karonto evaṁ avaca:
root_text.dn31:2.9: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, pituvacanaṁ sakkaronto garuṁ karonto mānento pūjento kālasseva uṭṭhāya rājagahā nikkhamitvā allavattho allakeso pañjaliko puthudisā namassāmi—
root_text.dn31:2.10: puratthimaṁ disaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ disaṁ pacchimaṁ disaṁ uttaraṁ disaṁ heṭṭhimaṁ disaṁ uparimaṁ disan”ti.
root_text.dn31:2.12: “Na kho, gahapatiputta, ariyassa vinaye evaṁ cha disā namassitabbā”ti.
root_text.dn31:2.13: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, bhante, ariyassa vinaye cha disā namassitabbā?
root_text.dn31:2.14: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tathā dhammaṁ desetu, yathā ariyassa vinaye cha disā namassitabbā”ti.
root_text.dn31:2.15: “Tena hi, gahapatiputta, suṇohi sādhukaṁ manasikarohi bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.dn31:2.16: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho siṅgālako gahapatiputto bhagavato paccassosi.
root_text.dn31:3.1: “Yato kho, gahapatiputta, ariyasāvakassa cattāro kammakilesā pahīnā honti, catūhi ca ṭhānehi pāpakammaṁ na karoti, cha ca bhogānaṁ apāyamukhāni na sevati, so evaṁ cuddasa pāpakāpagato chaddisāpaṭicchādī
root_text.dn31:3.2: ubholokavijayāya paṭipanno hoti. Tassa ayañceva loko āraddho hoti paro ca loko.
root_text.dn31:3.3: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
root_text.dn31:3.6: Pāṇātipāto kho, gahapatiputta, kammakileso, adinnādānaṁ kammakileso, kāmesumicchācāro kammakileso, musāvādo kammakileso.
root_text.dn31:3.9: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:
root_text.dn31:5.2: Chandāgatiṁ gacchanto pāpakammaṁ karoti, dosāgatiṁ gacchanto pāpakammaṁ karoti, mohāgatiṁ gacchanto pāpakammaṁ karoti, bhayāgatiṁ gacchanto pāpakammaṁ karoti.
root_text.dn31:5.3: Yato kho, gahapatiputta, ariyasāvako neva chandāgatiṁ gacchati, na dosāgatiṁ gacchati, na mohāgatiṁ gacchati, na bhayāgatiṁ gacchati;
root_text.dn31:5.4: imehi catūhi ṭhānehi pāpakammaṁ na karotī”ti.
root_text.dn31:5.6: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:

root_text.dn31:8.2: Sandiṭṭhikā dhanajāni, kalahappavaḍḍhanī, rogānaṁ āyatanaṁ, akittisañjananī, kopīnanidaṁsanī, paññāya dubbalikaraṇītveva chaṭṭhaṁ padaṁ bhavati.
root_text.dn31:8.3: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānānuyoge.
root_text.dn31:9.2: Attāpissa agutto arakkhito hoti, puttadāropissa agutto arakkhito hoti, sāpateyyampissa aguttaṁ arakkhitaṁ hoti, saṅkiyo ca hoti pāpakesu ṭhānesu, abhūtavacanañca tasmiṁ rūhati, bahūnañca dukkhadhammānaṁ purakkhato hoti.
root_text.dn31:9.3: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā vikālavisikhācariyānuyoge.
root_text.dn31:10.2: Kva naccaṁ, kva gītaṁ, kva vāditaṁ, kva akkhānaṁ, kva pāṇissaraṁ, kva kumbhathunanti.
root_text.dn31:10.3: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā samajjābhicaraṇe.
root_text.dn31:11.2: Jayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, jino vittamanusocati, sandiṭṭhikā dhanajāni, sabhāgatassa vacanaṁ na rūhati, mittāmaccānaṁ paribhūto hoti, āvāhavivāhakānaṁ apatthito hoti:

root_text.dn31:12.2: Ye dhuttā, ye soṇḍā, ye pipāsā, ye nekatikā, ye vañcanikā, ye sāhasikā. Tyāssa mittā honti te sahāyā.
root_text.dn31:12.3: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā pāpamittānuyoge.
root_text.dn31:13.2: Atisītanti kammaṁ na karoti, atiuṇhanti kammaṁ na karoti, atisāyanti kammaṁ na karoti, atipātoti kammaṁ na karoti, atichātosmīti kammaṁ na karoti, atidhātosmīti kammaṁ na karoti.
root_text.dn31:13.3: Tassa evaṁ kiccāpadesabahulassa viharato anuppannā ceva bhogā nuppajjanti, uppannā ca bhogā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti.
root_text.dn31:13.4: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā ālasyānuyoge”ti.
root_text.dn31:13.6: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:

root_text.dn31:16.6: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi aññadatthuharo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.

root_text.dn31:18.2: Pāpakampissa anujānāti, kalyāṇampissa anujānāti, sammukhāssa vaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, parammukhāssa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati.
root_text.dn31:18.3: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi anuppiyabhāṇī amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.

root_text.dn31:19.2: Surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānānuyoge sahāyo hoti, vikālavisikhācariyānuyoge sahāyo hoti, samajjābhicaraṇe sahāyo hoti, jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyoge sahāyo hoti.
root_text.dn31:19.3: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi apāyasahāyo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo”ti.

root_text.dn31:22.3: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi upakāro mitto suhado veditabbo.
root_text.dn31:23.1: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi samānasukhadukkho mitto suhado veditabbo.

root_text.dn31:23.3: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi samānasukhadukkho mitto suhado veditabbo.
root_text.dn31:24.1: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi atthakkhāyī mitto suhado veditabbo.

root_text.dn31:24.3: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi atthakkhāyī mitto suhado veditabbo.

root_text.dn31:25.3: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi anukampako mitto suhado veditabbo”ti.
root_text.dn31:25.5: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:
root_text.dn31:27.3: Puratthimā disā mātāpitaro veditabbā, dakkhiṇā disā ācariyā veditabbā, pacchimā disā puttadārā veditabbā, uttarā disā mittāmaccā veditabbā, heṭṭhimā disā dāsakammakarā veditabbā, uparimā disā samaṇabrāhmaṇā veditabbā.
root_text.dn31:28.1: Pañcahi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi puttena puratthimā disā mātāpitaro paccupaṭṭhātabbā—
root_text.dn31:28.2: bhato ne bharissāmi, kiccaṁ nesaṁ karissāmi, kulavaṁsaṁ ṭhapessāmi, dāyajjaṁ paṭipajjāmi, atha vā pana petānaṁ kālaṅkatānaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ anuppadassāmīti.
root_text.dn31:28.3: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi puttena puratthimā disā mātāpitaro paccupaṭṭhitā pañcahi ṭhānehi puttaṁ anukampanti.
root_text.dn31:28.4: Pāpā nivārenti, kalyāṇe nivesenti, sippaṁ sikkhāpenti, patirūpena dārena saṁyojenti, samaye dāyajjaṁ niyyādenti.
root_text.dn31:28.5: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi puttena puratthimā disā mātāpitaro paccupaṭṭhitā imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi puttaṁ anukampanti.

root_text.dn31:29.3: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi antevāsinā dakkhiṇā disā ācariyā paccupaṭṭhitā pañcahi ṭhānehi antevāsiṁ anukampanti—

root_text.dn31:29.5: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi antevāsinā dakkhiṇā disā ācariyā paccupaṭṭhitā imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi antevāsiṁ anukampanti.
root_text.dn31:29.6: Evamassa esā dakkhiṇā disā paṭicchannā hoti khemā appaṭibhayā.
root_text.dn31:30.1: Pañcahi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi sāmikena pacchimā disā bhariyā paccupaṭṭhātabbā—

root_text.dn31:30.5: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi sāmikena pacchimā disā bhariyā paccupaṭṭhitā imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi sāmikaṁ anukampati.

root_text.dn31:33.5: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi kulaputtena uparimā disā samaṇabrāhmaṇā paccupaṭṭhitā imehi chahi ṭhānehi kulaputtaṁ anukampanti.
root_text.dn31:33.6: Evamassa esā uparimā disā paṭicchannā hoti khemā appaṭibhayā”ti.
root_text.dn31:33.8: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:
root_text.dn31:35.1: Evaṁ vutte, siṅgālako gahapatiputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn31:35.3: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.dn31:35.4: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.dn31:35.5: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhagavā dhāretu, ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.

translation_text.dn31:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
translation_text.dn31:1.3: Now at that time the householder’s son Sigālaka rose early and left Rājagaha. With his clothes and hair all wet, he raised his joined palms to revere the various quarters—
translation_text.dn31:1.4: east, south, west, north, below, and above.
translation_text.dn31:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
translation_text.dn31:2.2: He saw Sigālaka revering the various quarters
translation_text.dn31:2.5: “Householder’s son, why are you revering the various quarters in this way?”
translation_text.dn31:2.7: “Sir, on his deathbed my father said to me:
translation_text.dn31:2.9: Honoring, respecting, and venerating my father’s words, I rose early and left Rājagaha and, with my clothes and hair all wet, raised my joined palms to revere the various quarters—
translation_text.dn31:2.10: east, south, west, north, below, and above.”
translation_text.dn31:2.12: “Householder’s son, that’s not how the six directions should be revered in the training of the Noble One.”
translation_text.dn31:2.13: “But sir, how should the six directions be revered in the training of the Noble One?
translation_text.dn31:2.15: “Well then, householder’s son, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.dn31:3.1: “Householder’s son, a noble disciple gives up four corrupt deeds, doesn’t do bad deeds on four grounds, and avoids six drains on wealth. When they’ve left these fourteen bad things behind they have the six directions covered.
translation_text.dn31:3.2: They’re practicing to win in both worlds, and they succeed in this world and the next.
translation_text.dn31:3.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn31:3.5: What four corrupt deeds have they given up?
translation_text.dn31:3.6: Killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, and lying: these are corrupt deeds.
translation_text.dn31:3.7: These are the four corrupt deeds they’ve given up.”
translation_text.dn31:3.8: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn31:3.9: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn31:4.4: astute people don’t praise these things.”
translation_text.dn31:5.1: “On what four grounds do they not do bad deeds?
translation_text.dn31:5.2: One does bad deeds prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.
translation_text.dn31:5.3: When a noble disciple is not prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice,
translation_text.dn31:5.4: they don’t do bad deeds on these four grounds.”
translation_text.dn31:5.5: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn31:5.6: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn31:6.2: out of favoritism, hostility, cowardice, or stupidity,
translation_text.dn31:6.4: like the moon in the waning fortnight.
translation_text.dn31:6.5: If you don’t act against the teaching
translation_text.dn31:6.6: out of favoritism, hostility, cowardice, and stupidity,
translation_text.dn31:6.8: like the moon in the waxing fortnight.”
translation_text.dn31:7.1: “What six drains on wealth do they avoid?
translation_text.dn31:7.2: Habitually engaging in the following things is a drain on wealth: consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants; roaming the streets at night; frequenting festivals; gambling; bad friends; laziness.
translation_text.dn31:8.1: There are these six drawbacks of habitually consuming beer, wine, and liquor that cause intoxication.
translation_text.dn31:8.2: Immediate loss of wealth, promotion of quarrels, susceptibility to illness, disrepute, indecent exposure; and weakened wisdom is the sixth thing.
translation_text.dn31:8.3: These are the six drawbacks of habitually consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.
translation_text.dn31:9.0: 6. Six Drawbacks of Roaming the Streets at Night
translation_text.dn31:9.1: There are these six drawbacks of roaming the streets at night.
translation_text.dn31:9.2: Yourself, your partners and children, and your property are all left unguarded. You’re suspected of bad deeds. Untrue rumors spread about you. You’re at the forefront of many things that entail suffering.
translation_text.dn31:9.3: These are the six drawbacks of roaming the streets at night.
translation_text.dn31:10.1: There are these six drawbacks of frequenting festivals.
translation_text.dn31:10.2: You’re always thinking: ‘Where’s the dancing? Where’s the singing? Where’s the music? Where are the stories? Where’s the applause? Where are the kettledrums?’
translation_text.dn31:10.3: These are the six drawbacks of frequenting festivals.
translation_text.dn31:11.1: There are these six drawbacks of habitually gambling.
translation_text.dn31:11.2: Victory breeds enmity. The loser mourns their money. There is immediate loss of wealth. A gambler’s word carries no weight in public assembly. Friends and colleagues treat them with contempt. And no-one wants to marry a gambler, for they think:
translation_text.dn31:11.3: ‘This individual is a gambler—they’re not able to support a partner.’
translation_text.dn31:11.4: These are the six drawbacks of habitually gambling.
translation_text.dn31:12.1: There are these six drawbacks of bad friends.
translation_text.dn31:12.2: You become friends and companions with those who are addicts, carousers, drunkards, frauds, swindlers, and thugs.
translation_text.dn31:12.3: These are the six drawbacks of bad friends.
translation_text.dn31:13.1: There are these six drawbacks of habitual laziness.
translation_text.dn31:13.2: You don’t get your work done because you think: ‘It’s too cold! It’s too hot. It’s too late! It’s too early! I’m too hungry! I’m too full!’
translation_text.dn31:13.3: By dwelling on so many excuses for not working, you don’t make any more money, and the money you already have runs out.
translation_text.dn31:13.4: These are the six drawbacks of habitual laziness.”
translation_text.dn31:13.5: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn31:13.6: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn31:14.2: some call you their dear, dear friend,
translation_text.dn31:14.3: but a true friend is one
translation_text.dn31:14.4: who stands by you in need.
translation_text.dn31:14.8: these six grounds ruin a person.
translation_text.dn31:14.12: in both this world and the next.
translation_text.dn31:14.13: Dice, women, toddy, song and dance;
translation_text.dn31:14.14: sleeping by day and roaming at night;
translation_text.dn31:14.16: these six grounds ruin a person.
translation_text.dn31:14.17: They play dice and drink beer,
translation_text.dn31:14.18: and consort with women loved by others.
translation_text.dn31:14.19: Associating with the worse, not the better,
translation_text.dn31:14.20: they diminish like the waning moon.
translation_text.dn31:14.21: One who is broke and destitute due to toddy,
translation_text.dn31:14.25: When you’re in the habit of sleeping late,
translation_text.dn31:14.26: seeing night as time to rise,
translation_text.dn31:14.28: you can’t keep up the household life.
translation_text.dn31:14.31: When the young neglect their work like this,
translation_text.dn31:14.33: But one who considers heat and cold
translation_text.dn31:14.34: as no more than blades of grass—
translation_text.dn31:14.35: he does his duties as a man,
translation_text.dn31:15.1: “Householder’s son, you should recognize these four enemies disguised as friends:
translation_text.dn31:15.2: the taker, the talker, the flatterer, the spender.
translation_text.dn31:16.1: You can recognize a fake friend who’s all take on four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:16.3: Giving little, they expect a lot.
translation_text.dn31:16.4: They do their duty out of fear.
translation_text.dn31:16.5: They associate for their own advantage.
translation_text.dn31:16.6: You can recognize a fake friend who’s all take on these four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:17.1: You can recognize a fake friend who’s all talk on four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:17.2: They’re hospitable in the past. They’re hospitable in the future. They’re full of meaningless pleasantries. When something needs doing in the present they point to their own misfortune.
translation_text.dn31:17.3: You can recognize a fake friend who’s all talk on these four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:18.1: You can recognize a fake friend who’s a flatterer on four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:18.2: They support you equally in doing bad and doing good. They praise you to your face, and put you down behind your back.
translation_text.dn31:18.3: You can recognize a fake friend who’s a flatterer on these four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:19.1: You can recognize a fake friend who’s a spender on four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:19.2: They accompany you when drinking, roaming the streets at night, frequenting festivals, and gambling.
translation_text.dn31:19.3: You can recognize a fake friend who’s a spender on these four grounds.”
translation_text.dn31:19.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn31:19.5: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn31:20.4: and one’s a comrade who spends.
translation_text.dn31:20.6: these four enemies for what they are
translation_text.dn31:20.7: and keeps them at a distance,
translation_text.dn31:20.8: as they’d shun a risky road.”
translation_text.dn31:21.1: “Householder’s son, you should recognize these four good-hearted friends:
translation_text.dn31:21.2: the helper, the friend in good times and bad, the counselor, and the one who’s sympathetic.
translation_text.dn31:22.1: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s a helper on four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:22.2: They guard you when you’re negligent. They guard your property when you’re negligent. They keep you safe in times of danger. When something needs doing, they provide you with twice the money you need.
translation_text.dn31:22.3: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s a helper on these four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:23.1: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s the same in good times and bad on four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:23.2: They tell you secrets. They keep your secrets. They don’t abandon you in times of trouble. They’d even give their life for your welfare.
translation_text.dn31:23.3: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s the same in good times and bad on these four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:24.1: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s a counselor on four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:24.2: They keep you from doing bad. They support you in doing good. They teach you what you do not know. They explain the path to heaven.
translation_text.dn31:24.3: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s a counselor on these four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:25.1: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s sympathetic on four grounds.
translation_text.dn31:25.2: They don’t delight in your misfortune. They delight in your good fortune. They keep others from criticizing you. They encourage praise of you.
translation_text.dn31:25.3: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s sympathetic on these four grounds.”
translation_text.dn31:25.5: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn31:26.2: one the same in both pleasure and pain,
translation_text.dn31:26.6: these four friends for what they are
translation_text.dn31:26.8: like a mother the child at her breast.
translation_text.dn31:26.11: They pick up riches as bees
translation_text.dn31:26.13: And their riches proceed to grow,
translation_text.dn31:26.14: like a termite mound piling up.
translation_text.dn31:26.16: a householder does enough for their family.
translation_text.dn31:26.17: And they’d hold on to friends
translation_text.dn31:26.18: by dividing their wealth in four.
translation_text.dn31:26.21: And the fourth should be kept
translation_text.dn31:27.1: “And how, householder’s son, does a noble disciple cover the six directions?
translation_text.dn31:27.2: These six directions should be recognized:
translation_text.dn31:27.3: parents as the east, tutors as the south, partner and children as the west, friends and colleagues as the north, bondservants and workers as beneath, and ascetics and brahmins as above.
translation_text.dn31:28.1: A child should serve their parents as the eastern quarter in five ways, thinking:
translation_text.dn31:28.2: ‘I will support those who supported me. I’ll do my duty for them. I’ll maintain the family lineage. I’ll take care of the inheritance. When they have passed away, I’ll make an offering on their behalf.’
translation_text.dn31:28.3: Parents served by the children in these five ways show sympathy to them in five ways.
translation_text.dn31:28.4: They keep them from doing bad. They support them in doing good. They train them in a profession. They connect them with a suitable partner. They transfer the inheritance in due time.
translation_text.dn31:28.5: Parents served by their children in these five ways show sympathy to them in these five ways.
translation_text.dn31:28.6: And that’s how the eastern quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.
translation_text.dn31:29.1: A pupil should serve their tutor as the southern quarter in five ways:
translation_text.dn31:29.2: by rising for them, by serving them, by listening well, by looking after them, and by carefully learning their profession.
translation_text.dn31:29.3: Tutors served by their pupils in these five ways show sympathy to them in five ways.
translation_text.dn31:29.4: They make sure they’re well educated and well drilled in memorization. They clearly explain all the knowledge of the profession. They introduce them to their friends and colleagues. They provide protection in every region.
translation_text.dn31:29.5: Tutors served by their pupils in these five ways show sympathy to them in these five ways.
translation_text.dn31:29.6: And that’s how the southern quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.
translation_text.dn31:30.1: A husband should serve his wife as the western quarter in five ways:
translation_text.dn31:30.2: by treating her with honor, by not looking down on her, by not being unfaithful, by relinquishing authority to her, and by presenting her with adornments.
translation_text.dn31:30.3: A wife served by her husband in these five ways shows sympathy to him in five ways.
translation_text.dn31:30.4: She’s well-organized in her work. She manages the domestic help. She’s not unfaithful. She preserves his earnings. She’s deft and tireless in all her duties.
translation_text.dn31:30.5: A wife served by her husband in these five ways shows sympathy to him in these five ways.
translation_text.dn31:30.6: And that’s how the western quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.
translation_text.dn31:31.1: A gentleman should serve his friends and colleagues as the northern quarter in five ways:
translation_text.dn31:31.2: giving, kindly words, taking care, equality, and not using tricky words.
translation_text.dn31:31.3: Friends and colleagues served by a gentleman in these five ways show sympathy to him in five ways.
translation_text.dn31:31.4: They guard him when they’re negligent. They guard his property when they’re negligent. They keep him safe in times of danger. They don’t abandon him in times of trouble. They honor his descendants.
translation_text.dn31:31.5: Friends and colleagues served by a gentleman in these five ways show sympathy to him in these five ways.
translation_text.dn31:31.6: And that’s how the northern quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.
translation_text.dn31:32.1: A master should serve their bondservants and workers as the lower quarter in five ways:
translation_text.dn31:32.2: by organizing work according to ability, by paying food and wages, by nursing them when sick, by sharing special treats, and by giving time off work.
translation_text.dn31:32.3: Bondservants and workers served by a master in these five ways show sympathy to him in five ways.
translation_text.dn31:32.4: They get up first, and go to bed last. They don’t steal. They do their work well. And they promote a good reputation.
translation_text.dn31:32.5: Bondservants and workers served by a master in these five ways show sympathy to him in these five ways.
translation_text.dn31:32.6: And that’s how the lower quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.
translation_text.dn31:33.1: A gentleman should serve ascetics and brahmins as the upper quarter in five ways:
translation_text.dn31:33.2: by loving deeds of body, speech, and mind, by not turning them away at the gate, and by providing them with material needs.
translation_text.dn31:33.3: Ascetics and brahmins served by a gentleman in these five ways show sympathy to him in six ways.
translation_text.dn31:33.4: They keep him from doing bad. They support him in doing good. They think of him with kindly thoughts. They teach him what he does not know. They clarify what he’s already learned. They explain the path to heaven.
translation_text.dn31:33.5: Ascetics and brahmins served by a gentleman in these five ways show sympathy to him in these six ways.
translation_text.dn31:33.6: And that’s how the upper quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.”
translation_text.dn31:33.8: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn31:34.8: a householder does enough for their family.
translation_text.dn31:34.12: they’re the kind who win glory.
translation_text.dn31:34.15: those consistent in conduct, the intelligent:
translation_text.dn31:34.16: they’re the kind who win glory.
translation_text.dn31:34.17: The inclusive, the makers of friends,
translation_text.dn31:34.18: the bountiful, those rid of stinginess,
translation_text.dn31:34.19: those who lead, train, and persuade:
translation_text.dn31:34.20: they’re the kind who win glory.
translation_text.dn31:34.23: and treating equally in worldly conditions,
translation_text.dn31:34.24: as they deserve in each case;
translation_text.dn31:34.25: these ways of being inclusive in the world
translation_text.dn31:34.26: are like a moving chariot’s linchpin.
translation_text.dn31:34.27: If there were no such ways of being inclusive,
translation_text.dn31:34.30: for what they’ve done for their children.
translation_text.dn31:34.31: But since these ways of being inclusive do exist,
translation_text.dn31:34.32: the astute do regard them well,
translation_text.dn31:35.1: When this was said, Sigālaka the householder’s son said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn31:35.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn31:35.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn31:35.5: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
